definition:
Let $X$ be a metric space and let $f\colon X\to X$ be a homeomorphism.
Suppose $\mathcal F= \{\Lambda_1,\dots,\Lambda_k\}$ is a family of
compact invariant sets for $f$. Define a relation $\rightarrow$ on
$\mathcal{F}$ by $\Lambda_i \rightarrow \Lambda_j$ if
$$W^u(\Lambda_i)\cap W^s(\Lambda_j) - \bigcup_{l=1}^k \Lambda_l \neq \emptyset,$$
that is, if the unstable set of $\Lambda_i$ intersects the stable set of
$\Lambda_j$ outside the union of the $\Lambda_l$’s.

A cycle for $\mathcal F$ is a sequence $\{n_i:i=1,\dots,j\}$ such that
$$\Lambda_{n_i}\rightarrow \Lambda_{n_{i+1}}$$ for $1\leq i<j$ and
$$\Lambda_{n_j}\rightarrow \Lambda_{n_1}.$$ With some abuse of notation,
we can write this as
$$\Lambda_{n_1}\rightarrow\Lambda_{n_2}\rightarrow\cdots\rightarrow\Lambda_{n_j}\rightarrow\Lambda_{n_1}.$$

If $\mathcal{F}$ has no cycles, then we say that it satisfies the
*no-cycles condition*.
